meanings.def: used with uncountable nouns or plural countable nouns to mean ‘an amount of’ or ‘a number of’, when the amount or number is not given
examples: There's still some wine in the bottle.
Have some more vegetables.

meanings.def: used to refer to certain members of a group or certain types of a thing, but not all of them
examples: Some people find this more difficult than others.
Some people never seem to put on weight while others are always on a diet.
I like some modern music (= but not all of it).

meanings.def: a large number or amount of something
examples: It was with some surprise that I heard the news.
We've known each other for some years now.
We're going to be working together for some time (= a long time).

meanings.def: a small amount or number of something
examples: There is some hope that things will improve.

meanings.def: used with singular nouns to refer to a person, place, thing or time that is not known or not identified
examples: There must be some mistake.
He's in some kind of trouble.
She won a competition in some newspaper or other.
I'll see you again some time, I'm sure.

meanings.def: used to express a positive or negative opinion about somebody/something
examples: That was some party!
Some expert you are! You know even less than me.

related: you win some, you lose some

examples: fearsome
quarrelsome

meanings.def: a group of the number mentioned
examples: a foursome

meanings.def: used to refer to an amount of something or a number of people or things when the amount or number is not given
examples: Some disapprove of the idea.
You'll find some in the drawer.
Here are some of our suggestions.

meanings.def: a part of the whole number or amount being considered
examples: All these students are good, but some work harder than others.
Some of the music was weird.

meanings.def: and a lot more than that
examples: We got our money's worth and then some.

idioms.def: and a lot more than that
examples: We got our money's worth and then some.
Some thirty people attended the funeral.
He needs feeding up some.
‘Are you finding the work any easier?’ ‘Some.’
